probabilistic inference from knowledge stored in complex probability distributions, and in
Section II-E and

for problems that are NP-hard
[32]).

Computational complexity theory has taught us that many practically important CSPs
belong to the class of NP-hard problems
[32], which means that there is practically no hope of solving these problems
on a Turing machine (or any classical digital computer) within a number of computation steps that does not increase
exponentially with the size of the problem.

Affect is the “body's way of preparing itself for action in a given circumstance by adding a quantitative

Batson et al. [11]

 dimensions [12].

Sentiments are defined by Cattell [18] as “an acquired and relatively

[19] has a similar definition; sentiments are “socially constructed

[20] defined sentiment as “a more or less enduring disposition

Cattell [18] further pointed out that the “functioning of sentiments

 Thus, the object has come to possess more or less an enduring power to “evoke relatively intense and frequent
 reactions, positive or negative in a person” [20].

Cattell [18] distinguished between sentiments and opinions in his analysis
 by pointing out that an individual possesses a sentiment and experiences a complex secondary or derived emotion,
 whereas an opinion is not possessed but is an expression of personal interpretation of information.

The two inner MZMs in the arm are named child MZM and the outer MZM is named parent MZM according to the specification of I/Q modulator [12].

The goal of this work is to extend the analysis by considering the impact of limited ER of the child MZMs, since the state-of-the-art optical I/Q modulator typically has a child MZM ER of around 20 dB [12].

For commercially available optical I/Q modulators [12] with 20-dB ER, to achieve a 1-dB or less Q-factor penalty, the DAC resolution required for 4-QAM, 16-QAM, 32-QAM, and 64-QAM modulation formats are less than 4, 4.7, 5.3, and 6.3, respectively.

We showed in
[3] and 
[6] that vehicles are the most significant source of signal attenuation and
variation in highway environments.

Based on these studies and by using the findings from our previous work described in
[3], which identified surrounding vehicles as an important factor in V2V
communication, our approach is to use simple geographical descriptors of the simulated environment (outlines of
buildings, foliage, and vehicles on the road) to classify V2V links into three groups:


•
Line of sight (LOS)—links that have an unobstructed optical path between the transmitting and
receiving antennas;

•
Non-LOS due to vehicles (NLOSv)—links whose LOS is obstructed by other vehicles;

•
Non-LOS due to buildings/foliage (NLOSb)—links whose LOS is obstructed by buildings or
foliage.

Locations of the vehicles can
be obtained from vehicular mobility models (e.g., SUMO
[10]), GPS logs, or aerial photography 
[16], whereas the dimensions of vehicles can be either measured or drawn from
statistical distributions
[3].

First, on highways, obstructing vehicles are the most important
objects for modeling the V2V channel, as the roads are predominantly straight, and the largest portion of communication
happens over the face of the road
[3].

Specifically, through measurements
in open space, urban, suburban, and highway environments, as well as by consulting the existing V2V measurements (e.g.,
[22]–

[24]), we concluded that large-scale signal variations for LOS links are well
approximated by a two-ray ground reflection model, whereas for NLOSv links, we use an experimentally validated model in
[3], which we extend to include diffraction off the sides of vehicles, in
addition to diffraction over the vehicle roofs.

For modeling NLOSv links, we employ the model described in 
[3], which accounts for additional attenuation due to vehicles by taking into
consideration their exact locations and dimensions and applying the multiple knife-edge diffraction
[27] over the rooftops of obstructing vehicles.

These results,
which are in line with previous measurements reported in
[3], 
[6], and 
[36], demonstrate the ability of 

\$\hbox{GEMV}^{2}\$ to incorporate the impact of different types of
vehicular obstructions.

When it comes to evaluating the impact of vehicular obstructions, apart from our previous studies described in 
[3] and 
[6], several experimental studies emphasized the importance of obstructing
vehicles.

Apart from our previous work reported in
[3], to the best of our knowledge, there have only been two studies aimed at
explicitly introducing vehicular obstruction in propagation modeling.

Abbas et al.
[36] performed V2V measurements and showed that a single vehicle can incur
attenuation of more than 10 dB, which is in line with the results reported in
[3].

The results regarding LOS and NLOSv conditions shown in

consider the main type of propagation mechanism for the respective link type (specifically, two-ray ground reflection
model for LOS and vehicles-as-obstacles model for NLOSv
[3]), with additional small-scale signal variation proportional to the number of
vehicles and the area of buildings and foliage around the communicating pair.

The contributions of this article are four-fold: (i) we propose several new improved energy detector structures for unknown deterministic signals (Gaussian signal but not zero mean) perturbed by zero-mean Gaussian noise and/or fading and present an exact analytical framework for characterizing the receiver operating characteristics (ROC) of such detectors; (ii) we show that the need for a bulky and expensive antenna array at each of the energy detectors in [9] can be eliminated (i.e., very attractive from a practical implementation viewpoint especially for small form factor sensor nodes and handheld devices) by mapping the orthogonal spatial dimensions of the time-domain samples in [9] into orthogonal time dimensions proposed in this article; (iii) we demonstrate that it is possible to harness time diversity and provide additional flexibility for the PU signal protection by combining the local binary hard decisions made at different partitions of a stand-alone energy detector using a simple t-out-of-u decision fusion rule (in contrast to the multiple energy detectors employed in cooperative spectrum sensing scenario).
This can be achieved by either having multiple detection circuits in conjunction with an antenna array [9] or through spatially distributed energy detectors [10].
